entry.title: Re: How to ask a question in SAP Community >= 2024
entry.content:
@Jelena_Perfiljeva, I totally agree.

Even after posting many posts, I usually use 5-10 minutes just to figure out how to do it correctly - and its not because I'm stupid.
I think all complex web forums has some kind of guide and Rules of engagement, but the level complexity here is so high and I agree that the major part of the problem is Ux design failure.

Just look at the top of this thread. I have a comment at the top of the thread with just with a "?" in it. That was an attempt to answer your post, but I managed to find the wrong "Post Comment" button and as it was not possible to remove the comment from that wrong place, I changed it to a "?". So even when we have found the relevant thread, the UI makes it difficult to interact correctly.

PS. The problem with the one-line comments is really annoying. I solve that problem by writing a quick one-liner and then immediately push the Edit Comment button. Then I get the multiline editor and can re-write the full comment.

Best Regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: S4HANA Public Projects - WBS vs WOs
entry.content:
Hello @Egbert_de_Jong 

Thank you for your question

1. How to cope with multi disciplinary projects?

I am not sure I fully understand the whole question you packaged into your question 1. However, what I know works well in practice is to use a hybrid structure. Which basically means:

  • You should use WBS for financial governance. This includes Budget, AVC, settlement, reporting, etc.
  • Your maintenance orders or work orders should be executed under the WBS. This may include your daily planning granularity, scheduling your operations, etc.

Enterprise Projects are used to plan, collect and settle cost, while you can still run your execution through the operational objects like orders.

The Blog: The two project control possibilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Enterprise projects and professional services projects also provides some good insights.

I would avoid putting all execution detail into WBS only, especially when your planning and dispatch reality is based on orders. I would also avoid overbuilding the WBS hierarchy to compensate for any missing operational granularity in your processes, because it may degrade performance and your ability to use it for large structures.

My recommendation is for you to keep WBS as your financial backbone and keep orders as your execution layer. Ensure you only add minimum WBS levels for your governance and settlement.

2. We have 3 WBS levels below project def. Is that the max as per design or can this be expanded?

No, it is not the hard maximum. Public cloud however, advices to keep your enterprise projects reasonably sized for performance reasons. See KBA 3462842 for more details. Basically, saying it is only recommended to expand beyond 3 if it adds real governance value and not to use extra levels to model operational detail that should be handled by orders.

3. How to route delegated Budget holders at WBS level?

 A clean core approach you can use is the Flexible Workflow. You can then route approvals based on the WBS responsibility concept. See Workflow Step Configuration, Configuration: Workflow for Service Entry Sheets and Flexible Workflow for Service Entry Sheets - Lean Services for more details.

A pattern that works well and you should consider is:

  • You maintain a person on each WBS that represents a delegated budget holder
  • Ensure your PO and SES carry the correct WBS account assignment
  • You configure your SES workflow step recipient to pic the WBS responsible person.

Remember to keep one WBS per SES or per PO item, so the workflow can only find the designated responsible person.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Product Compliance / EHS Classic (WWI; Expert server)
entry.content:
Introduction

In EHS classic we use WWI to design and later generate (and e.g. sent to the customer) the document (e.g. Safety Data Sheet). This will change with Product Compliance. We do not need WWI anymore.

EHS Classic

I encourge you to read CAREFULLY the cookbook: how to set up a "WWI generation Server". In the last weeks / months: I have seen so many BAD installations for WWI generation server that I was getting frustrated (and it took me and others days to make it right).

Yes we know: we have a "windows box" part (with same challenges) and a SAP part.

All of the issues as determined have been in SAP. SO PLEASE: do not underestimate to understand the set up to run a "WWI server" in SAP.

There is (from my point of view) less understandin existing: what is the use of SAP transaction CGSADM; and what is the connection to WWI.

There i less understanding existing: what are the steps in SAP to prepare a WWI server which is up and running and what is the difference between a "synchron" and "asynchron" WWI.

But luckily: we do not to take care regarding WWI anymore with Product Compliance.

Product Compliance

So we need to split: for "documents" we will use in th future the "Adobe" solution. For "calculations" (e.g. as with EHS Exter Server): we will see what we get and who will deliver what (what part of the E2E solution will  come from SAP and what may be from 3E).

In the past many models have been discussed. For me still not clear what will come exactly.

One piece was: we do calculation outside of SAP S/4 HANA; some other are saying: no we do the calculation in SAP; some are saying: calculation might happen in SAP BTP. 

So many unknowns.

I encourage you to participate (if possible) in the next SAP meeting in march 2026; which will provide (according to best knowledge) an overview:

a.) what was achieved with S/4 HANA on premise version 2025

b.) provide some indication: what is planned for S/4 HANA 2027

c.) and may be provide overview regaridng current content of "Cloud version".

Wish you the best for 2026; Start now to take a look on "Product Compliance"

etc.

entry.title: SAP BTP - IS - ( IA | CPI ) - The Commander's Blueprint: Rebuilding B2B EDI Governance with SAP BTP.
entry.content:
Spoiler

Disclaimer: This article is written for Integration Architects, Solution Architects, B2B Leads, Managers, and Integration Consultants dealing with B2B EDI modernization to SAP BTP Integration Suite. It focuses on governance, strategy, not in quick wins.

Instead, it is a strategic orientation on the mindset and professional positioning required of an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant (IA + CPI).

My goal is to provide a strategic guide on how to approach a scalable solution and lead a business transformation, rather than just explaining how to configure isolated components without considering the entire ecosystem.

Please note: This is not a "click-by-click" tutorial or a step-by-step technical manual.

Introduction

In my previous article, SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant - Part IV - I outlined a path for integration professionals to evolve beyond the “CPI Developer” label toward true SAP BTP Integration Suite specialization.

Today, I want to put this into practice by discussing a critical scenario: the modernization of B2B/EDI processes in S/4HANA projects.

Many companies adopting Rise with SAP and Clean Core methodologies still make the strategic mistake of maintaining legacy platforms (such as Seeburger or OpenText) or, even worse, they attempt to rebuild decades of EDI logic within massive and manual CPI iFlows. The result is what I call the "EDI-T-REX Legacy": a heavy, undocumented architecture that no one dares to touch.

SAP BTP Integration Advisor (IA) is the tool that breaks this cycle, transforming what would be a "Frankenstein" of code into clean governance, where the functional team regains control over what is being mapped.

My journey with Integration Advisor has been one of deep technical discovery. Until recently, it was an area I had not explored in depth — which makes the insights shared here the result of focused study and hands-on experimentation rather than inherited project patterns.

Quick Project Setup B2B EDI

Let me show you an imaginary project conversation.

The following imaginary conversation highlights a common mistake: treating SAP BTP Integration Advisor as an afterthought rather than the core of your EDI governance and structural framework.

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

Our next challenge: global B2B EDI migration with ~3 international partners across legacy platforms.

We're dealing with a chaotic mix of standards (EDIFACT, ANSI X12, VDA, RosettaNet), each with partner-specific deviations.

The real question: Are we migrating platforms or just moving decades of undocumented business semantics?

Will we implement a true semantic layer or replicate "partner-to-partner spaghetti" in a modern tool ?

Who actually owns these standards and partner lifecycle today in SAP BTP Integration Suite ?

SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Commander 

OK I understand your worry, my proposal is rebuilding semantic governance, not just migrating EDI flows.

Using SAP Integration Advisor's MIG objects, we centralize business semantics. MAGs replace tribal knowledge with explicit, automated rules.

TPM shifts ownership from people to platform every contract becomes a managed asset for seamless partner onboarding.

Reality check: Integration Advisor exposes our weaknesses. 

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

Clear asnwer thank you but how do we avoid adapter hell (HTTPS, AS2, SFTP, OFTP2, X.400)?

Number range  collisions across partners, hidden Groovy "quick fixes" for encoding/delimiters, SAP API Management boundary: REST wrappers vs. batch mindset?

BTP concerns: Handling Functional Acknowledgments (997/CONTRL) without doubling message volume. Support teams already drown in dashboards—APIM + TPM adds complexity.

Single Pane of monitoring ?

SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Commander

Use SAP's standard EDI Integration Templates and TPM V2—not custom iFlows. Place APIM in front for quota management and spike control.

SAP BTP manages ICN per partner, preventing collisions. Integration Advisor handles delimiters/encoding—no Groovy hacks. Status correlation links acknowledgments (997/CONTRL) to original messages, avoiding dashboard clutter.

Monitoring: Application Correlation IDs track payloads and B2B and CPI monitoring

Legacy protocols (X.400, OFTP2): Third-party adapters only when needed. Maximize native Integration Suite for Clean Core architecture.

Enablement: I'll personally train the EDI ops team on MIGs, MAGs, and TPM.

Bottom line: Platform complexity handled. You focus on strategy; I'll deliver the engine and team.

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

Fair enough. That is exactly the level of technical clarity and leadership I was looking for to validate the viability of this project. You’ve addressed the architectural risks and, more importantly, the human element of this migration.

Phased approach: Start with 2 strategic vendors and 2 EDI formats to build our "Golden Template." This establishes confidence in SAP Integration Advisor (MIG, MAG, TPM) without overwhelming operations.

Your mission: Prepare the platform and enablement materials. Align the front-line team with your vision.

Let's start to think in possible remove the "T-Rex" and enter a new governance era. Time to execute.

Thank you for your support—let’s get to work.

The "T-Rex" Scenario: Why the fear of change is your greatest risk?

In the image below, I describe what I call the "Legacy Trap Mindset." It is the famous "T-Rex": an EDI ecosystem that no one wants to touch because "it has been working for 10 years."

The problem is that no one knows where the documentation is, how the transformations were built, or how to perform quick maintenance in case of an error. Within the context of Clean Core, keeping this dinosaur alive creates an innovation bottleneck.

Image 1 - trap mindste legacy for B2B EDI

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: Where does Integration Advisor truly fit?

Although IA is underutilized in the market, the hands-on mastery I have acquired by studying this tool in depth allows me to face this chaos with a clear strategy. If I were leading this migration today, my stance as an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant would be structured on two pillars:

Enablement and Trust (The Human Factor)

I would provide a practical internal course to give confidence to the business team, B2B specialists, and SAP functional consultants. They need to understand that IA is not just another "IT tool," but a platform that returns mapping control to those who truly understand the business rules. It leverages Machine Learning and SAP’s Crowd Encyclopedia to accelerate what used to take weeks of manual coding.

Governance and Architecture (The Technical Factor)

This is where many fail: creating MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines) and MAGs (Mapping Guidelines) in isolation only speeds up technical construction but doesn't solve the underlying disorder. My role would be:

  • Defining Semantics: Creating MIGs with real business meaning.
  • The "Canonical Path": Structuring the integration using a canonical model ( When two types of EDI message type are semantic with the respective message type from SAP side)
  • Materialization via TPM: Demonstrating how Trading Partner Management (TPM) must be used to materialize integration templates and contracts.

Without alignment between the contracts defined in TPM and the mappings in IA, the most valuable assets are lost: governance, traceability, and reusability. It is not about "copying and pasting" legacy logic, but using IA to clean the architecture—leaving SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) only with lightweight technical execution and lean iFlows.

“MIG and MAG build - TPM governs - Without TPM, there is no sustainable B2B integration.” 

Image 2 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Internal Enablement on SAP Integration Advisor.

References
  • SAP BTP Integration Advisor Demo
  • How to build custom B2B Interface using Integration Advisor , AS2 Adapters and API Proxy
  • Integration Advisor: Overview of components for building B2B integration content and further reading

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: fit into MIGs?

The first step in killing the "T-Rex" is the correct construction of MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines). As a consultant, my role is to guide the team at the base of the pyramid:

  • 1:1 Structure: Creating one object per Message Type (EDI or SAP), ensuring granularity.
  • Business Semantics: Going beyond the technical side by defining rules, field usage, and documenting Codelists.
  • Facilitation: Acting as the bridge that translates technical standards (EDIFACT/X12) into the actual requirements of the SAP process.

Responsibilities and Roles of the SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - IA - MIG

What the IA Consultant DOES:

  • Facilitation: Teaches how to operate the IA and apply the correct semantics to fields.
  • Technical Oversight: Ensures the MIG follows the standard (1:1) and remains technically reusable.
  • Mentorship: Guides the documentation of codelists and qualifiers.

What the IA Consultant DOES NOT do:

  • Define Business Rules: The business decides what it needs; the consultant only shows where to implement it.
  • Data Governance: The consultant delivers the structure, but responsibility for the data itself lies with the process owner.
  • Flow Decisions: Does not interpret commercial rules without validation from Key Users.

“MIG defines clarity, semantics, and standards."

Image 3 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Providing guidance on where and how to create a MIG and select the message type.

References - MIG
  • Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • integration content advisor: Create a customized interface using MIG editor
  • Integration Advisor – multi-payload support for MIG creation
  • Integration Advisor – direct support of EDI payloads
  • Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • integration content advisor: Discover B2B/A2A standard libraries
  • Integration Advisor : Use of cXML Type System Exporting to CPI

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: fit into MAG?

If the MIG is the definition of the object, the MAG (Mapping Guideline) is where the transformation magic happens. The consultant acts as the guide who materializes this connection.

What the Consultant DOES:

  • Connectivity: Guides the correct selection of Source and Target MIGs.
  • Targeted Mapping: Explains how to perform field-to-field mapping, ensuring that the semantics defined in the MIG are respected.
  • Conversion Logic: Implements and teaches how to use basic conversion functions to adjust data between standards (e.g., transforming date formats or units of measure).
  • Artifact Generation: Demonstrates how to generate the schemas (XSD) and transformations (XSLT) that the CPI will utilize.

What the Consultant DOES NOT do:

  • Define Complex Business Logic: The consultant implements the technical conversion, but calculation rules or commercial decisions must come from the functional side.
  • Map Without a Base: The consultant must not start a MAG if the MIGs have not been properly validated by the business.

“The MAG is not a technical mapping; it is an adapter between meaning and the platform.”

Image 4 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - How to create a MAG from MIG outbound and MIG Inbound

References MAG
  • Integration Advisor: complex mapping code for dimension conversion in SAP B2B
  • Base-/Overlay Mappings for Integration Advisor
  • Integration Advisor – Download MAG Simulation Result as EDI Payload
  • Accessing Headers and Properties in Integration Advisor (IA) Mapping Guidelines (MAG) with the Global Parameters
  • Integration Advisor: Conditional Mapping Feature
  • Integration Advisor: Conditional mapping in MAG to pass one value from the multiple occurrence of an element, based on other element's value
  • Complex Mappings 
    • SAP MAG mapping many occurrence node to 1 occurrence node and take last occurrence values to target
    • SAP TPM MAG or IA MAG :choose or multiple if conditions
    • SAP TPM MAG conditional mapping target node it's child

Where does an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant fit into TPM?

The SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant must guide and enforce the use of TPM (Trading Partner Management) as a true governance layer, to be honest, TPM is not a "ten-headed beast" or some unreachable diamond; however, the most critical part is the definition of Identifiers within the EDI envelopes. If these are configured incorrectly, the agreement will fail to trigger even if everything else is perfect. I will demonstrate this below.

What is NOT the responsibility of the (IA/TPM) Consultant

For a migration to be sustainable, the consultant must not take over tasks that belong to business management or day-to-day operations.

The Consultant DOES NOT:

  • Define Commercial Rules: Does not decide legal terms, freight conditions, or SLAs. The business defines the rule; the consultant only configures it.
  • Operational Execution (TPM): Is not responsible for the continuous registration of hundreds of partners, certificate maintenance, or agreement versioning once the project has stabilized.
  • Contract Negotiation: Does not act in the alignment of deadlines or contractual obligations with external suppliers and customers.

Summary: The consultant designs the architecture and the migration process. The operational life of the tool (onboarding new partners and business decisions) must be managed by the company's internal EDI specialist team.

“MIG defines the meaning, MAG defines the destination, TPM defines the contract.”

Image 5 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - How to create a TPM

References
  • TPM Onboarding Demo
  • Use TPM, IA, CI to Efficiently Manage and Run Complex B2B Transactions
  • Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration

The Developer’s Playground: Where SAP CPI Experts Take Control

Now, we enter the territory where we, as SAP CPI experts, have total dominance.

Once all the steps above are completed—specifically once the TPM is configured and the Agreement is accepted and deployed—something critical happens behind the scenes.

We aren't just "connecting pipes" anymore; we are orchestrating a dynamic, metadata-driven engine.

Image 6 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - CPI Implementation

Technical Deep Dive: Standard Packages and the "Plain ID" Trap

I will now explain the possibilities and the path I took to streamline this integration. I am intentionally ignoring the option of building a fully manual, custom iFlow. Such an approach would be unnecessarily complex, time-consuming, and redundant given the standard packages available.

Standard EDI Package Options:

EDI Integration Templates for SAP Integration Advisor - A versatile set of iFlows for various scenarios.

Cloud Integration - Trading Partner Management V2- The complete governance suite.

The TPM V2 Workflow:

  • Step 1: Ingress (Generic, depends on the channel: HTTP, SFTP, SOAP, IDoc, ProcessDirect, AS2).
  • Step 1b: Persistency (Write Message to Message Queue).
  • Step 2: Interchange Processing Flow V2 (The "Brain").
  • Step 3: Receiver Communication Flow V2.

My Assessment: After debugging every step in both packages, the standalone EDI Integration Templates work perfectly if you have your MIGs and MAGs ready, standalone iFlow is only valid for small-scale integrations.

Image 6 - Inject Process MAG to SAP CPI Iflow

 

Image 7 - Injection Steps, Connection, Package, Iflow and bummm !

The "Isolation Test" Strategy: Validating the MAG

Pro-Tip: I used the standalone iFlow to validate my mapping (MAG) before moving to TPM, injecting the MAG directly into a copy of the standard iFlow and testing with a Content Modifier using plain text (X12 850), I could validate the logic instantly. This is crucial because if you try to debug the Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow without a prior test, grab a coffee and bring plenty of patience and papers because you are going to cry as me.

Crucial Recommendation: Pay close attention to the Validate and Analyze EDI Interchange step configuration. I suggest mirroring the settings in Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow V2 exactly.

How to do it:

  • Configure the Pre and Post-processing steps with your generated XSD and XSLT files.
  • Run a test using a Content Modifier with the raw EDI "N" format (in my case, an X12 850) as plain text.
  • It doesn’t matter if it’s EDI to IDoc or, as I tested, EDI to OData—the communication channel is secondary at this stage.

Note on Testing: Please keep in mind that I am an expert in integration, not in business semantics or specific EDI file structures. Many of my test files were generated manually or extracted from internet, which caused significant issues during the validation phase.

Image 8 - Validacao da MAG e verificado do EDI Splitter

The "Agreement Plain ID" Headache

Once everything is configured and the agreement is deployed in TPM, it generates a unique "Information Package" for the trading partner based on identifiers. This is where the Agreement Plain ID comes in the configuration of identifiers in the Company and Partners regards the exchange header validation.

Imagem 9 - Aggremment Active in TPM

After successfully completing these steps, you will generate the "Trading Partner Information Package." This process creates a unique identification string based on the company's and the partner's identifiers.

This object—the Agreement Plain ID—is exactly what caused me so much frustration during the implementation.

What does a string like SOAP-ASC-X12--004010-BUYERCO-ZZ----SAP-ZZ----850 actually mean? It is a concatenation of the identifiers found in the EDI header:

  • SOAP: Partner Sender Channel
  • ASC-X12--004010: Message Type
  • BUYERCO-ZZ: Partner Identifier
  • SAP-ZZ: Receiver Identifier
  • 850: Transaction Code (Orders)

The Trap: If these identifiers are registered incorrectly in Company and Partner sides —even by one character—the integration will fail. There is a Groovy script of nearly 1,000 lines inside the standard package that handles this logic. I had to debug it to understand why my agreement wasn't being found.

Forced error: ISA*00*...*ZZ*BUYERCO*ZZ*SAP2... (The "SAP2" mismatch prevents the iFlow from finding the Agreement in the TPM table).

 
Imagem 10 - Bug between Partner Agremment ID and the header detail of the message as EDI or SAP Message Type

Crucial: Number Range Synchronization Ensure the Number Range is identically named in the TPM Company/Partner, the Agreement, and the SAP CPI Number Range monitor. Failure to align these exactly will trigger errors. I also experienced a platform bug where a locked Agreement prevented the deletion/update of the INC_UN_EDIFACT range.

 

Image 11 - Number Range

Pro Tip: Custom Number Ranges If a TPM Agreement gets stuck (e.g., locking INC_INB_EDIFACT), use a Custom Number Range. This bypasses platform bugs and is a best practice for high-volume scenarios to prevent duplicate sequence numbers across different partner agreements, remember that this was test with ODETTE EDIFACT 96A not with another scenario X12.

In the platform that I have access there is somehow to agreements that was not delete 100% locking the INC_INB_EDIFACT, I have no idea how to delete or if must open SAP ticket for it:

 

Image 13 - Trading Agrement locking the INC_INB_EDIFACT.
SAP CPI Iflow - Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow V2 - for SAP TPM - SAP Integration Advisor and always failed in this step:

 

Image 12 - Set Control Numers fails

Error: javax.script.ScriptException: java.lang.Exception: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Error reading number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT @ line 46 in setControlNumbers.groovy, cause: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Error reading number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT

I debugged another simple iFlow and it worked, so I still couldn't understand the cause of these locked records. I opened a thread on SAP SCN but received no response. I then tested a workaround—which I do not recommend—that involved modifying the standard CPI iFlow in Step 2, though I later reverted it to the original version.

Image 13 - Workaround Iflow to check outside TPM config the number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT 

Image 14 - Workaround Iflow to check outside TPM lock range number INC_UNB_EDIFACT

Inside the Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow, there is a Local Integration Process for mapping. Since MAGs are based on XSLT and have some limitations, you can use ProcessDirect to call PRE and POST processing flows for complex logic or fine-tuning.

Image 15 - Local Integration Process - PRO and POS mapping processing

Now, let’s look at the "perfect scenario"—everything built, configured, and ready for action. In this case, I decided to push the limits: I used Scenario 1 with a SOAP call executing an EDI Flat File via a SOAP envelope.

The result? Don't worry about Step 5; I am simply looping the message back into the CPI for processing.

Imagem 16 - Full processing
 

Stop Guessing, Start Proving

You don’t have to replace everything at once. The most viable path is a low-risk POC (Proof of Concept). Pick a single, non-critical flow, apply the Integration Advisor methodology, and witness the efficiency firsthand. Once the value is proven, you can execute a robust, confident migration.

Industrialized Automation vs. Manual Labor

The large-scale EDI migrations, tools like int4 Shield (formerly IFTT) and Figaf automate what would be manual labor.

Key benefits:

  • Extract legacy definitions → auto-convert to TPM entries and iFlows
  • Months of development → weeks of configuration
  • Capture real messages → run through new system → automatic comparison
  • Ensures 100% mapping fidelity without partner involvement

Result: Migration becomes governance and audit, not error-prone manual work. Predictable timelines, lean team, no supply chain disruptions.

  • Int4 Shield (formerly IFTT):
    • Int4 Shield - Migration to SAP Integration Suite
    • SAP News - Test Automation for SAP Integration Suite
    • SAP Store - Advanced Business Process Testing
  • Figaf Tool:
    •  Figaf - SAP EDI Migration Tooling
    • Figaf Docs - Connecting to Integration Advisor
    • Figaf Blog - Migrating EDI to SAP Integration Suite

 Image 17 - The Beginning of the T-Rex Extinction 

Conclusion

Modernizing EDI on SAP BTP isn't just moving iFlows from on-premise or cloud it's remove the control from outside to insade with governance and structure.

Using Integration Advisor as the semantic brain and CPI as the agile engine, we transition from technical workarounds to managing true business assets.

Creating strategic content connecting architectural vision with technical execution takes weeks of deep work. If this "Commander's Blueprint" helped you see beyond standard tutorials.

Drop a comment. Share your perspective. LET'S GO!

Best regards,

Viana

Good bye T-Rex !

entry.title: SAP Brownfield Conversions
entry.content:
A Brownfield #SAP S/4HANA implementation, also known as a system conversion, involves migrating your existing SAP ERP system to S/4HANA. This approach retains your historical data, customizations, and configurations, making it different from a Greenfield (new implementation) approach.

  • Project Kick-off and Scoping - Define the project scope, objectives, timeline, and budget. It is very important to clearly define the project roles & responsibilities.
  • System Analysis and Readiness Check - Analyze your existing SAP system to assess its readiness for conversion. Run the readiness check report delivered by SAP.
  • Simplification Item Check - Analyze the simplification items in S/4HANA to identify any functionalities that have changed or been removed. Gauge the potential impact on business processes and customizations.
  • Custom Code Analysis and Remediation - Analyze your custom code to ensure compatibility with S/4HANA.
  • Hardware and Infrastructure Assessment - Assess your existing hardware and infrastructure to ensure it meets the requirements for S/4HANA.
  • Business Process Analysis - Look for any possible optimizations.

     

    • Conversion cycles - Sandbox conversion is a kind of first simulation of the production cutover. Update your existing SAP system to the required support package level and perform necessary preparations for the conversion. Migrate your existing database to SAP HANA. Perform the actual S/4HANA conversion using the Software Update Manager (SUM) tool.
    • Testing and Validation - Unit Testing , Integration Testing & Performance testing.
    • Training and Go-Live - End user training , Cutover planning ,Go-live execution & PGLS.
    • System Monitoring - Monitor the system's performance and stability and make necessary adjustments to optimize performance.
    • Continuous Improvement - Continuously evaluate the system and identify areas for improvement and optimization.
    • Some important aspects are Custom Code Management ,Downtime Management ,Data Migration Complexity and Change Management.

     

    The only way to master the conversion projects is to deliver them for customers!!!

    Happy Reading.

entry.title: Re: Transfer Advance with Tax on sale / purchase from one...
entry.content: SAP does not automatically reassign profit center/business area for tax lines in transfer postings. The recommended approaches are either to reverse/repost the advance or to configure substitution/BAdI logic for tax line derivation.

entry.title: Re: Systems not able to process messages via SAP Cloud Connector as of Q1/2026
entry.content:
If not really required to have own certificates in the JVM trust store itself, it is recommended to store these own certificates for LDAP and e-mail communication via TLS in the respective Cloud Connector trust store instead.
Please also see the Tip at
https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/update-java-vm#both-operating-systems 

Doing so would save you from the problem that Ulrich described.

entry.title: Embedded TM (S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025): Cross–company-code transport planning
entry.content:
Hi all,
we are designing a central transport organization within a corporate group:

  • Multiple producing company codes create outbound deliveries / transport demands.

  • A central service company performs transport planning and execution in one embedded TM system (S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

  • The dispatcher must consolidate freight units from different producing entities into shared trucks (multi-pickup, multi-drop), using own fleet and external carriers.

  • The service company must recharge transportation costs internally to the producing company codes (target: IC billing in SD/MM).

Documentation confusion:

  • SAP Help for Internal Settlement states it moves costs from the purchasing org of the execution document (e.g., freight order / freight booking), but it also references the sales org of the forwarding order as part of the execution context. 

  • SAP Help for the Group Logistics Scenario describes central consolidation of transportation requirements .

    • However, SAP learning content for the embedded LSP / group logistics process indicates it requires integration of orders/deliveries from an external ERP/S/4 system with a TM component (which sounds like Side-by-Side/distributed).

  • In addition, SAP Notes 3615236 mentions that Group Logistics in embedded TM may not be supported 

Questions:

  1. In embedded TM (S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025), is it supported to plan freight units from multiple company codes on a single freight order owned by a central service company without forwarding orders and without using Side-by-Side / external TM integration? Actually, all the OTR should be available as freight units and the dispatcher could consolidate them into a freight order. No need for a forwarding order, right?

  2. For internal cost recharge, can we achieve a true cost split by producing company code and trigger/enable IC billing (SD/MM) based on TM settlement outputs without using Forwarding Orders?

Thanks a lot for any guidance, especially from projects using embedded TM with cross-company planning and internal cost allocation.

Function ‘HTTP destination request’ in SAP Build Apps.

I am developing an application in SAP Build Apps that needs to upload attachments to
S/4HANA using the standard OData service API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV.
The upload is triggered by a button press in the UI, and the attachment is selected by the
end user.
I am following an SAP blog that explains how to upload attachments from SAP Build Apps
using the HTTP Destination Request component. In the blog, the implementation is done
using DMS (Document Management Service) and the approach works correctly, including
the CSRF handling and multipart/form-data POST request. In my case, I cannot use DMS
and I need to upload attachments using GOS (Generic Object Services) via the standard
OData service API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV. I am trying to adapt the same approach shown
in the blog to GOS, but this is where I am currently blocked with the 403 Forbidden error.


Source: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/connect-sap-build-apps-with-dm
s-free-projects-videos/ba-p/13986096

The only difference in the destination details is the Proxy Type, which is set to ‘Internet’ and in my case is OnPremise.

------

In the Request body i send key: media with value: <picture jpg>

Path: /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/AttachmentContentSet
Headers with the relative value:
● Slug: (Slug of the image)
● LinkedSAPObjectKey: (LinkedSAPObjectKey data from a Notification created
before this)

● Content-Type: image/jpeg

If I press F12 and look at the network tab I can see the Response, the error 403 Forbidden.

But then If I tried with Postman it works.

And on the S/4HANA usign the transaction /IWFND/TRACES I can see an error exactly on
the moment when a HEAD request is executed


Someone have a clue about this?
Thanks

You would need a 3rd-party UFL (User Function Library) to support some types of barcodes.

Barcode UFL typically depend on installing a special font on the machine processing the Crystal Report.
Perhaps you simply need to install the UFL.

My CUT Light UFL generates barcodes without any font dependency. The barcodes are generated on the fly as images, and are loaded into the report using the 'Graphic Location' expression in the property of a dummy image. Here is the relevant user manual section.

entry.title: Re: Workitem Language change
entry.content:
@Chandu You didn't understand what has said Venu: if you transport the entire workflow task (R3TR PDTS 92000334, just an example), it will transport all the workitem text translations altogether (all the lines of table HRS1206 for this workflow task, i.e. the texts in all languages). Plus the translations of the other texts of the task.

I confirm that Venu solution works.

For information, the menu Translation --->ABAP Objects -->Transport Object corresponds to the shortcut key Ctrl+F1. Note that it displays 3 lines, each line is a key starting with PDTS92000334 (just an example) and ends with 08 (texts of task container elements), 02 (short and long codes of the task) and 06 (workitem text of the task).

Also, the workitem text can be directly accessed via SE63 > Button "Short texts" > A5 (User Interface texts) > TLGS (Transport Logical Objects) > PDTS92000334 06 (06 starting at the 41st character). In SE63, you may also enter directly the shortcut TLGS in the OK Command Field (explained here: Solved: Translation of Task and Work item description - SAP Community).

PDTS92000334                            06

entry.title: Re: Translation of Task and Work item description
entry.content: To complete the correct answer by @Joerg_S, you'll see 3 lines in SE63 for R3TR PDTS 91000123, the workitem text corresponds to the line which has the number 06 at the end. It's also explained in this thread: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/workitem-language-change/qaa-p/14314081.

entry.title: Re: CAP application gives 401 unauthorized error after de...
entry.content:
Hi Daivid,

If the application is not a production application, you can use :

  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "[production]": {
        "auth": "mocked"
      }
    }
  }

Please note that this is not a safe practice. It is just to see whether your CAP service is deployed properly.

If you have deployed the application and want to access it from the Workzone, then update your xs-app.json with the following route :

{
      "source": "^/your-service/(.*)$",
      "target": "/your-service/$1",
      "destination": "<your-desitnation-name>",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
      "csrfProtection": true
    },

entry.title: How to extend a standard SAP Workflow Task? (change a description or workitem text, or add an event)
entry.content:
What is the correct way to change the workitem text of a standard Workflow Task? (I mean, a task provided by SAP)

Same question for changing a description or adding an event.

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: How to extend a standard SAP Workflow Task? (change a description or workitem text, or add an ev
entry.content:
If you want to extend without doing a repair:

  1. Start the transaction code PFTS or PFTC (or indirectly via other transaction codes like SWDD) and click Display (do not click Change).
  2. For changing the workitem text in the tab "Basic Data", click on the button "Redefine text" and enter the new text.
  3. For changing a description in the tab "Description", click on the button "Change text" and enter the new text.
  4. For adding a triggering or terminating event in the eponymous tab, click on the button "Change" in the bottom table "Other events" and enter the new event.
  5. On saving, that will ask for a transport task of type development/correction, which will contain one entry R3TR TDAT PDTS_CUST with keys corresponding to the extended Workflow Task, for the 3 customer extension tables HRC1002 (task redefined descriptions), HRC1206 (task redefined workitem texts) and HRC1212 (task additional events).
  6. If you want to translate, the only solution is to log in each language, as explained in this thread: Solved: Workflow Workitem text redefinition translation - SAP Community. Or you may edit manually or programmatically the three HRC* tables, but at your own risk!

Instead of doing a customer extension, you may click "Change" on the selection screen, but that will do a repair which means that the changed object will appear in the list of modifications when upgrading the software (SPAU):

  1. Start the transaction code PFTS or PFTC (or indirectly via other transaction codes like SWDD) and click Change.
  2. Modify anything you want, the classic way. Any way, the customer extension buttons and frames won't be proposed in change mode (they appear only in display mode).
  3. On saving, that will ask for a transport task of type repair, which will contain one entry R3TR PDTS <workflow task> with keys corresponding to the modified Workflow Task, for all the tables linked to the PDTS object type (transaction SOBJ), like HRS1000, HRS1002 (task descriptions), HRS1200, HRS1201, HRS1202, HRS1206 (task workitem texts), HRS1210, HRS1211, HRS1212 (task events), etc.
  4. If you want to translate the descriptions or the workitem texts, you may use SE63. See this answer: Solved: Workitem Language change - SAP Community.
  5. For information, the list of repairs appears in the table SMODILOG, even the translations.

entry.title: Re: Workflow Workitem text redefinition translation
entry.content: So, no better solution than logging in each language to translate. For information, I have cross-linked this thread in this general question about extending the SAP standard tasks: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-forum/how-to-extend-a-standard-sap-workflow-task-change-a-description-or-workitem/td-p/14314105.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2025: AXIGMA impulsa el talento local
entry.content:
El pasado 8 de noviembre de 2025, Ciudad del Este fue sede del primer SAP Inside Track en Paraguay, un evento que marcó un hito en la historia de nuestra comunidad tecnológica. Más de 100 profesionales SAP se dieron cita para compartir experiencias, aprender y construir redes profesionales que perdurarán en el tiempo.

La Formación: La Clave del Crecimiento Profesional
En el ecosistema SAP, la capacitación oficial es uno de los activos más valiosos que un profesional puede adquirir. Obtener formación estructurada, con contenido actualizado y respaldada por partners certificados, abre puertas a nuevas oportunidades laborales y permite dominar las tecnologías más demandadas del mercado. Es una inversión en el futuro profesional que marca la diferencia entre tener conocimientos básicos y convertirse en un especialista reconocido.

AXIGMA: Apostando por el Talento Paraguayo
Queremos expresar nuestro profundo agradecimiento a AXIGMA, quien como auspiciante oficial del SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2025, demostró su compromiso con el desarrollo del talento local de una manera excepcional.
AXIGMA puso a disposición de nuestra comunidad 2 cursos completos de capacitación oficial SAP, cada uno con 100 horas de formación intensiva en tecnologías S/4HANA:

  • Formación del Programa SAP MM - Material Management en S/4 HANA
  • Formación del Programa SAP FI - Finanzas en S/4 HANA

Este tipo de formación representa una oportunidad invaluable para profesionales que buscan certificarse en los módulos más solicitados del mercado. No es solo un curso: es una puerta de entrada al siguiente nivel profesional, con contenido oficial, instructores especializados y certificación reconocida internacionalmente.

¡Anunciamos a los Ganadores!
Tras el sorteo realizado durante el evento, nos complace enormemente anunciar a los dos afortunados ganadores que tendrán acceso a esta formación de alto nivel:

🎓 Pablo Gamarra - Ganador de la Capacitación Oficial SAP MM Material Management en S/4HANA


🎓 Agustín Pastrana - Ganador de la Capacitación Oficial SAP FI Finanzas en S/4HANA


¡Felicitaciones a ambos! Les deseamos mucho éxito en su proceso de capacitación. Estamos seguros de que aprovecharán al máximo esta oportunidad y que los conocimientos adquiridos impulsarán sus carreras hacia nuevos horizontes.

¿Quieres Ser el Próximo Ganador?
El próximo año podrías ser tú quien gane premios como estos. Formación de primer nivel, acceso a contenido exclusivo, oportunidades de networking con profesionales destacados y la posibilidad de participar en sorteos con premios que pueden transformar tu carrera profesional.
Mantente conectado con nuestros canales oficiales y únete a la SAP Community Group para no perderte ninguna novedad sobre el próximo evento.

Gracias a Toda la Comunidad
Desde el equipo organizador, queremos agradecer a todos los que hicieron posible este sueño: participantes, speakers, voluntarios y especialmente a nuestros sponsors, que con su apoyo hacen posible que nuestra comunidad siga creciendo.

Esto es solo el comienzo. ¡Nos vemos en el próximo SAP Inside Track Paraguay!

¿Quieres conocer más sobre capacitaciones SAP? Visita www.axigma.com

entry.title: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Over the last year or so, the dialogue around Shift Left architectures and working as an enabler for Data Products has intensified across the industry. What was once maybe a niche architectural preference in the modern data stack is now increasingly a topic for enterprises aiming to scale their data operations. For decades, most data architecture followed a "Shift Right" pattern, based mostly on table-oriented replication patterns where backend applications were not held responsible for defining and implementing extraction logic, and centralized data teams were left in charge to act as "data janitors"—cleaning, modeling, and fixing data in a downstream lakehouse.

The idea of Shift Left is an architectural evolution for modern data management and platforms that treats data as a governed, high-quality data extract on the level of a curated and well defined business entity or even a Data Product at the moment of its birth. By moving responsibility for quality and semantic definition to the "left", orienting it to real business entities and closer to the place where the data is really generated, the burden of data preparation is addressed where the context is strongest. With that, it’s easy to imagine how the downstream "cleanup" cycle can become unnecessary or significantly streamlined under this model.

Several key benefits have fuelled this recent momentum:

 

  • Faster Time-to-Insight: Data is born ready for consumption, removing the weeks or months spent in logical (re-)definition and build, as well creating ingestion and cleaning data pipelines.
  • Semantic Fidelity: Business logic is defined by those who understand the context of the data best—the source domain experts.
  • Improved Data Quality: Automated validation at the source prevents structural and logical "garbage" from entering the analytical ecosystem.

 

SAP has made Data Products a central pillar of its analytics and data management portfolio, particularly through SAP Business Data Fabric. This approach allows enterprises, so the promise, to leverage quickly pre-defined, semantically rich products directly from the source by using the capabilities and rich semantics of the so-called CDS-views.

1. Previously in this theatre: Extractors as the Original Data Products

While the term "Data Product" feels modern, the principle has existed for decades within the SAP ecosystem. Standard Extractors (in SAP BW) were the original proto-data products. They abstracted technical table and join complexities, managed reliable deltas, and preserved business logic (semantics) during extraction. While remaining a vendor-specific approach, it paved the way for SAP BW as the central DW solution for SAP centric data environments. Can 0MATERIAL also be seen a data product, with (most of) its extraction logic encapsulated in the 0MATERIAL* extractors?

The Shift Left movement is essentially an extension of this principle. We can now imagine, also for the “modern data stack”, that these "extractors" are moving from proprietary silos to a world where every system—SAP or otherwise—is expected to publish its data via an open, governed data Contract on business entity level.

2. The System-agnostic Catalog as a consequence

As the definition of a data products hence relies in the source system, in a Shift Left world, the Data Catalog should no longer be perceived as a component exclusive to the analytics environment. It becomes a globally valid, Cross-System Registry, centring and nurturing itself where the business logic actually lives: and this is, if consequently applied, in the ERP and backend systems.

In this model, the backend systems act as the Semantic Anchor. Definitions, business rules, and schemas are registered at the source. The Enterprise Catalog then acts as a discovery layer, allowing the analytical team to "subscribe" to these definitions rather than attempting to recreate them through guesswork.

While a Corporate Knowledge Graph can technically be built using traditional "Shift Right" methods—by retroactively mapping data in a central hub—the Shift Left approach acts as a fundamental accelerator. By mapping business entities and their relationships directly at the source, the organization moves toward a "Data Network" or Corporate Ontology. Again, SAP is going this way.

3. Effects on the Medallion Architecture

A consequent Shift Left implementation matures the traditional Medallion Architecture (Bronze ->  Silver ->  Gold) into a Readiness Hierarchy:

 

  • The Fading of Bronze: The raw, messy landing zone becomes obsolete. Because data is validated against a contract at the source, it bypasses the "dump" phase.
  • Silver as the "Data Product Entry": The Silver layer is no longer a processing stage for data engineers. It is the published interface of the backend team—a collection of high-quality, documented and understandable Data Products.
  • Gold as the space of synergy and joint interpretation: Gold remains the space for interpretation and combination. Here, products from different domains (e.g. Finance and sales) are joined to create holistic, cross-functional metrics and analytical applications of many types are brought into live.

 

4. Shift Left architectures also imply a significant shift in roles and responsibility

The most significant challenge for implementing consequently a shift-left architecture is the migration of accountability. This requires a fundamental change in team dynamics:

 

Specifically for SAP environments, it is important to note that SAP has effectively taken on this responsibility. As the owner and architect of the underlying backend application logic, SAP is increasingly expected to deliver corresponding data products and semantic definitions directly. This shifts the burden of initial structural definition from the customer's internal data team back to the software vendor, who must deliver accordingly to support the modern data fabric.

However, for customer-owned data producers (custom-built applications and microservices), the consequences are more demanding. These teams could no longer view data as a byproduct of their application. They must take on the role of a data provider, which implies:

 

  • Increased risk of Technical Debt: Development teams must build and maintain the infrastructure for data contracts and delta determination.
  • Skill Gap Challenges: Backend developers must acquire data modeling and semantic layering skills that were previously the domain of data engineers.
  • Operational Overhead: Data quality incidents are no longer "downstream problems" but production bugs that must be resolved by the source team.

 

A major strategic advantage of this shift is that Data Quality (DQ) and DQ fulfillment metrics are now located exactly where the data is born. By addressing DQ problems at the source, organizations can identify and resolve the root causes of errors in real-time, rather than applying reactive patches downstream. This proximity inherently leads to higher data quality and more accurate business reporting.

How other software vendors will act, and how quickly internal development teams can pivot to this new standard of accountability, remains to be seen.

5. A critical technical thing: Trustworthy Deltas

For Shift Left to sustain larger datasets, it relies on reliable delta determination with often cross-table dependencies in rather complex relations. able-oriented delta mechanisms introduce complexities on the receiver side when it comes to rebuilding the correct delta image of the businesss entity. Hence, the backend must provide a stream of changes on business entity level, not just a dump of data. Whether through transaction-like Log-Based CDC or the Transactional Outbox Pattern, the backend must guarantee that updates to complex, multi-table business objects are captured correctly. SAP’s multi-table CDC mechanism is right on track, even if for very large scenarios, more basic techniques could become necessary.

6. Dealing with Fragmented Sources

A common real-world problem occurs when multiple systems describe the same global entity. For example, three different regional SAP instances may each manage their own "Material" data. In a strict Shift-Left model, you cannot force a single backend to own the "Global Material" if they don't actually manage the other regions' data. Instead of defaulting to a centralized "Gold Layer" cleanup, consider these alternatives:

 

  • Regional Responsibility: Each regional system stays responsible for its own data product (the "Silver" layer). North America and Europe each publish their own high-quality Material products according to a shared contract.
  • Federated Identity Resolution: The challenge of unification is addressed by establishing a shared Semantic Standard across contracts. By mandating that each regional source provides a common global identifier (e.g., a GTIN or an MDM-supplied Global ID) as a mandatory field in its data contract, the technical "merger" is downgraded from a complex transformation to a simple join or union. This virtualization allows for a global view where source-specific attributes are treated as extensions of a core, harmonized entity, preserving local ownership while enabling global interpretability.
  • MDM Products: A dedicated Master Data Management (MDM) team publishes a "Linkage Product." Consumers then "subscribe" to both the regional Data Product and the Linkage Product to build their own global view, keeping ownership decentralized. This is a solution approach for many customers with spread out, but logical equivalent master data objects.
  • Analytical Extensions (ML-driven Attributes): Not all master data attributes are generated in the operational source. Advanced attributes like "Customer Lifetime Value" or "Churn Risk Clustering" are often the result of analytical processes or ML models. These should be treated as Data Product Extensions. they exist as specialized "Sidecar Products" that share the same global identifier. Consumers combine the operational "Silver" product with the analytical "Extension" product via a join. This is not contradictory to so-called “Closed loop scenarios”; rather, it provides a clean architectural separation. While the analytical insight is consumed as a product, the actual write-back of results into the ERP remains an operational task, ensuring the semantic definition is enriched without burdening the operational backend with analytical overhead.

 

7. Strategic Alignment: Adapting to Pre-Defined Semantics

SAP has taken the lead by pre-defining data products in its SAP Business Data Fabric. While this provides instant maturity (starting at "Silver"), it implies that SAP provides the core business semantics and definitions. For the customer, the choice is no longer about building the definition from scratch, but about accepting and adapting to these standardized SAP semantics. This shifts the organizational responsibility from "designing the truth" to "adhering to the standard" provided by the software vendor.

Conclusion

Consequential "Shift Left" is a clear organizational direction, but it is rarely a binary switch. It demands that backend teams stop viewing data as a byproduct and start treating it as a first-order deliverable. For many organizations, the trade-off remains a strategic choice: you either invest in upstream discipline and source-side engineering to achieve high-velocity scalability, or you rely on the proven, defensive strengths of a traditional Shift Right model to manage fragmented legacy landscapes.

The path forward will be usually a hybrid one, also given by constraints of each environment. While Shift Left provides the semantic foundation and quality required for AI-ready platforms in the place where data is generated, it succeeds only when the burden of stewardship is either automated by vendors like SAP or embraced as a core technical competency by internal development teams. Ultimately, the "chaos" of modern data is not solved by shifting it from one team to another, but by establishing a shared culture of accountability across the entire data value chain.


#ShiftLeft #DataArchitecture #DataProducts #DataStrategy #DataQuality #DataEngineering #Semantics #DataTeams

entry.content:
SOAP adapter in SAP BTP CPI supports both HTTP and HTTPS. 

HTTPS is supported for synchronous request–reply scenarios

Most productive landscapes block HTTP and allow only HTTPS

So the claim “BTP only supports HTTP (not HTTPS) for SOAP synchronous communication” is false.

entry.title: Re: How does Effort Deviation adjustment persist across p...
entry.content:
Hello @SVops 

Thank you for your question.

The Reset and Recalculate which in this case is Option A, is buttressed in the KBA 3617498 as the closest option. However, you should note that:

  • The adjustment is a compensation posted into the current Forecast Months for the overbooking or underbooking that happened before the Forecast Month.
  • Should you move the Forecast Month forward, the system recalculates the deviation based on your new horizon and the compensation shifts to the new Forecast Month. Which means the system does not cumulate across months.

So, when you look at that from one period to another period, it simply means:

  • Deviation is based on the gap between plan and actual up to that point in the periods before your Forecast Month. This is also explained in the KBA 3617498.
  • Compensation amount is posted by the system to offset prior under or over booking for your Forecast Month Period.
  • The earlier compensation does not stay in the old month; it is recalculated and appears in your new Forecast Month after you have changed Forecast Month.

The distribution mentioned in the KBA is about allocating within the forecast logic, for example across your demands, while the calendar period compensation is applied in the Forecast Month. So, it is not Option B and not Option C across calendar periods.

Your May 2024 example shows a +5 compensation was applied in the Forecast Month to offset your prior underbooking (rounding rules may also affect this). In other words, you are not seeing May only; you are seeing May plus the forecast month compensation for earlier periods.

In your CDS:

  • Check which period is currently set as the Forecast Month for that project.
  • Compare your ActualPlanDeviationEffort for; periods before Forecast Month and the Forecast Month itself.
  • Move your Forecast Month to the next period and re read the CDS; the compensation value should move to the new Forecast Month.

Here are a few references: Forecast Information for Engagement Project - Cube, Forecasting

Check out this Blog: Professional Services - Extracting Estimate At Completion (EAC) via CDS views

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Need to know how can Return Revenue GL can be assigne...
entry.content:
Hello @abulhasnat

1.  For exclusion, so the return condition is used and the standard one is ignored, I suggest you use Condition Exclusion in the same pricing procedure. Therefore, you should:

  • Try and create two conditions ZSTD for standard, ZRET for returns and assign different Account Keys.
  • Create an Exclusion group containing those conditions in your CBC pricing configuration.
  • Then assign the conditions to your pricing procedure and set the rule so only one gets involved.

So, that will ensure your pricing keeps only one and thereby standard condition is ignored for returns. See KBA 3641244, Condition Exclusion, and Condition Exclusion for Pricing Procedure for more guidance.

2.  You do not need to change Copy Control 102763 for custom field.

Yes, you often cannot edit 102763 in CBC. You should consider using Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents instead of copy control routines. You can:

  • First is to create the custom field in Custom Fields and Logic and enable it for Billing Document.
  • Then implement Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents to copy the value you need into the billing document custom field.
  • You should maintain Assign Data Transfer Route to Copying Control Setting for the delivered LR2 --> G2 copying relationship in CBC. This does not mean you are creating a new copy control entry, rather you are assigning the routine to the existing one.

After that, you can use that custom field in Revenue Account Determination to derive your return revenue GL.

See KBA 3269803, Assign the Data Transfer Routine to Copying Control Settings and Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents for more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Building a Graph Native AI Chatbot on SAP BTP
entry.content:
The true intelligence and accuracy of an enterprise AI chatbot depends on one thing, Data Access. While most chatbots rely on standard API calls to fetch information, it hits a wall when dealing with complex, interconnected business logic.

The Problem: Chatbot's rely on API calls to extract data from source system. APIs are designed for transactions and not data exploration. For example, if a user asks, 'Show me the total revenue impact of C4C service tickets related to S/4HANA orders delayed by supplier issues,' .

A traditional chatbot is stuck. It would need to orchestrate a number of cross-system OData calls, join the data in memory, and calculate the results often resulting in high latency or timeouts.

The Solution: SAP HANA Graph

The better approach is by combining the LLM with the Graph Schema in SAP HANA, we can bypass these limitations entirely. In this blog, I will show you how to build a Graph-Native Agentic AI that understands your data relationships intuitively.

Instead of viewing data as API endpoints, we model it as a Property Graph. Here, the business entities (like Customers, Sales Orders, Service Tickets, Products) are represented as Vertex(Nodes) and their relations are the Edges.

Deep-Node Traversals:

The graph allows the chatbot to traverse relationships instantly. In a single query it can hop from a Customer node -->Sales Order node -->Line Item node --> Product node, collect the necessary data and send it to the LLM which is then sent to the user.

The graph engine natively supports aggregations(SUM,COUNT) directly in the database layer during node traversal

We can physically link a C4C Service Ticket node to a S/4HANA Sales Order node. The graph schema identifies only the data relation and not the system of origin.

Representation of interconnected Business Objects that form a graph.

 

Let's See it in Action - Demo Video

Conceptualizing a graph traversal can be difficult, so let’s look at how the chatbot handles a query involving Sales Cloud scenario:

Why I chose Property Graph?

  • vs. Knowledge Graphs: While Knowledge Graphs focus on semantics and inference (great for unstructured data), Property Graphs focus on structure and attributes, which fits enterprise data better.
  • Rich Context: Relationship between Business Objects carry properties. For example, a relationship between a Customer and a Product isn't just a relationship link, it contains transaction details like: CUSTOMER --> BOUGHT {ProductID: 10005824, Date: 20/01/2026, Quantity: 5, Price: $100} --> PRODUCT
  • Mathematical Aggregations: Property Graph engines are optimized to perform aggregations (Sum Revenue, Count Tickets, Avg) on the fly during data traversal. 
  • Accuracy: We rely on strict graph schema definitions to ensure the LLM generates accurate, hallucination free queries.

Architecture:

To enable this real-time graph agent, I implemented a robust data fabric on SAP BTP.

Real-time data fabric

We utilize SAP Datasphere to act as the pipeline for data source & replication. By replicating the raw tables into SAP HANA via Datasphere, we ensure the data is real-time. Once the data is replicated to HANA, the Graph Workspace is created on top of these tables, defining the vertexes (nodes) and edges (relationships) virtually.

Handling Federated Data Scenarios

In cases where data cannot be not replicated to SAP HANA(volume constraints), the architecture adapts seamlessly. The Graph LLM retains its logic and identifies the necessary nodes(vertices) and query parameters based on the user prompt. Instead of generating a openCypher query these parameters are mapped to optimized OData calls to the source system. This ensures a streamlined, real-time federation strategy that shows the precision of a graph traversal.

Schema Injection

The graph schema(the definition of Nodes and Edges) is injected to LLM at run time. Based on the user query the LLM will first identify the nodes, data traversal path and the logic.

For the query: “Who are my top 5 customers by sales volume who also have open critical tickets?”

The LLM determines the execution plan:

  • Nodes Identified: BusinessPartner (Customer), SalesOrder, ServiceRequest
  • Traversal Paths:
    • BusinessPartner --> SalesOrder (To calculate volume)
    • BusinessPartner <-- ServiceRequest (To find the open tickets)
  • Filters Applied:
    • ServiceRequest.LifeCycleStatus = 'Open'
    • ServiceRequest.Priority = 'Critical'
  • Aggregation: Sum of SalesOrder.NetAmount grouped by Customer.
  • Ranking: Order by Sum Descending, Limit 5.

openCypher Query Generation

Once the LLM identifies the graph query plan, the actual openCypher query is generated programmatically using python. I did not use LLM here as the openCypher wrapped in HANA is tricky and requires precise syntax.

The openCypher query is executed directly against the SAP HANA Graph engine and the result is passed to the LLM to generate a natural language summary.

Transactional Updates (Write Scenarios)

For maintaining transaction data, the Agentic AI brings in a mandatory human-in-the-loop confirmation step before any data is written via a POST request. You can see the technical implementation steps for this human intervention logic in my earlier blog post.

User Interface & Deployment

The core Chatbot agent is deployed on SAP BTP. For the front end, I utilized SAP Build Apps to create a clean, low-code user interface. The app connects to the BTP agent and provides a seamless chat experience for the business user.

Conclusion

By moving from API loops to Graph Traversals, we unlock the true potential of Enterprise AI. We get the speed of database-level aggregation with the flexibility of natural language processing.

Reference:

Refer this blog to understand about the implementation of Agentic AI Chatbot using LangGraph - The power of AI Agents: My Journey with LangGraph

entry.title: Re: Balance Sheet/Income Statement - Multidimensional
entry.content:
Hello @jantoniomoyano3 

Thank you for your question

On your quest to modify FS Leaf External ID, the simple answer is the public cloud does not permit that. The reason is the field is a technical external ID used by the report logic which is not designed for user to maintain in the app or through configuration. Extensibility or customisation is also not supported for this report family.

Instead of that, you can however, maintain a business-friendly description in your Financial Statements Version and display those in your report instead of the external ID.

Below is a short description of what to consider:

In your Tenant, open Manage Global Hierarchies, open your FSV hierarchy, maintain the node of leaf texts, activate it, in your Balance Sheet statement, use the display with descriptions and not the external ID.

If your goal is only to not show YCOA, remove that column from the layout and save your view. You can do this in your report by opening settings, then go to Column, then unselect FS Leaf External ID and keep the descriptive fields. Finally save it as a variant or you may also bookmark it.

See KBA 3641756, Configuring a New Financial Statement Version and Balance Sheet / Income Statement - Multidimensional for more details.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

  • Outbound delivery created

  • Picking + PGI in supplying plant

  • GR in receiving plant

  • Stock arrives correctly and quantity is updated

My issue

But in the standard intra-company STO flow, the inventory value at GR remains the same as the issuing plant’s valuation, and the transportation cost is not added.

What I tried

  2. Posting freight through supplier invoice functions (planned/unplanned delivery costs)

  3. In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, is there an SAP-standard way to capitalize transfer freight on an intra-company STO (same company code) so it increases inventory value at the receiving plant?

entry.title: Streamlining Cost Sharing Process in SAP Grants Management
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

For those intereted in the public sector accounting, if they have ready my previous blog on SAP Grants Management An Introduction to SAP Grants Management ,  they must have got a good idea of how SAP Grants Management works to meet the sponsor reporting requirments . The blog explained in details the end to end process of obataining, posting and reporting Grants from Grantee perspective. In this article, we will be covering cost sharing part of SAP Grants Management.

In some grants, there is a clause as per MoU signed that Grantee will also be contributing to some cost of the project beside Sponsor who is already funding the project. This is where the concept of Cost sharing comes into picture and it plays a pivotal role in satisfying the sponsor'e resporting requirment without compromising the internal processes of Finance. We will now deep dive into some of key concepts of Cost Sharing in SAP Grants Management.

GM Fund Type:

In the grant master data, a fund of type external is always needed and there can only be one fund external fund in the grant, however we can always add fund of type internal within the grant for cost sharing scenarios. Funding received from the grantor are recorded on the External fund level and contribution from the grantee are recorded on the internal fund.

Grant Master Cost Sharing Fund

If you want to maintain cost sharing settings on the grant master you need to flag at least one internal fund for cost sharing.

The fund is available in budgeting, as well as on all commitment- and expense-generating transactions such as purchasing documents, travel commitment, direct FI expense postings etc. This allows the companies to separate the sponsor and grantee contributions for all the relevant business processes, and also in reporting.

The classifiction of fund as internal and external is mandatory for the cost sharing process which can be done in IMG>>Public Sector Management>>Grants Management>>Grantee Management>>Master Data>>Fund>>Maintain GM Fund Type for FM Fund Type

FM Fund Type

Capturing Cost Sharing in Grant:

Within a Grant, cost sharing can be done in two unique ways.

Additive Calculation of Cost Sharing budgets
The sponsor/grantor does not want to see the complete grant relevant project budget but he just defines his funding i-e the amount he can fund for the project.  The grantee’s contribution is then calculated as a percentage of the externally funded amounts (sponsor’s contribution) in order to cover the project. The grantee’s contribution is added to the sponsor’s funding.

Subtractive Calculation of Cost Sharing budgets (available as of release 603)
The sponsor wants to see the complete grant relevant project budget and defines their funding as a share of this total budget. Therefore the grantee’s contribution is then calculated as a percentage of the total amount (externally and internally funded). From the total the cost sharing is subtracted in order to have the sponsor’s contribution.

Budgeting Cost Sharing:

Budgeting of Cost Sharing is done in two steps
1.- Enter budget

2.- Allocate

These steps are based on the GM document type, where we can see what kind of funding it is: Sponsors funding, or Cost Sharing funding.

In GM_CREATE_BUDGET , I have entered net amount of 10M USD for the Grant as shown.

Budget Entry View-Sponsor

We can see the cost sharing information in the cost sharing tab as shown below.

Cost Sharing View-Grantee Contribution

At this point , we will post 10 Million USD sponsor budget for 3 years.

New we will choose document type configured exclusively for Cost Sharing as shown and post the Grantee share of Grant which is 260,000 USD.

Cost Sharing Budget-2.6 Million USD

Cost Sharing-Completed Allocation

GMAVCOVRW - Overview of GM AVC Values report shows both Sponsor and Grantee view of the Grant as shown below making the total Grant value based on the additive cost sharing rule to 12.6 Million USD.

GMAVCOVRW - Overview of GM AVC Values

Recording Actuals/Commitments:

Commitments and actuals on the grant with shared costs can be setup easily using the appropriate derivation rules for the postings. FMDERIVE and GMDERIVE have to be setup properly to accomodate the grants requirments. Consumption on above GM Account assignment can be done via FI posting or P2P process.

P2P-Commitment Generation

GM-GTE Commitment Document Overview

There is Useful KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003680745 to automate Cost sharing process using Rule Based Account Assignment , I will cover this process in some future blog.

Thank you for your time to read this blog 😊.

entry.title: Re: How to export a photo column (data type image) in a t...
entry.content:
See xp_write_file  or  WRITE_CLIENT_FILE system procedures.  The xp_write_file is relative to the server. If you want the files written to a client, use WRITE_CLIENT_FILE.  Here are examples use the demo datbase Products table.

-- save relative to the server
select xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\server\\' || ID || '.jpg', photo) from GROUPO.Products;

-- save relative to the client
set option allow_write_client_file = 'On';
select WRITE_CLIENT_FILE( 'C:\\\temp\\client\\' || ID || '.jpg', photo) from GROUPO.Products;
set option allow_write_client_file = 'Off';

 If you have more that one column that you want process, simply repeat the xp_write_file or WRITE_CLIENT_FILE for each of the columns.  For example, the following saves imageCol1 and ImageCol2  from table SampleTab.

select 
      xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\imageCol1\\' || ID || '.jpg', imageCol1)
    , xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\imageCol2\\' || ID || '.jpg', imageCol2)
from SampleTab

entry.title: Adding revenue contract and performance obligation to Fiori AppDisplay Line Items in General Entries
entry.content:
Why Add These Fields?

When using CBRR, SAP automatically enriches journal entries with revenue contract and performance obligation IDs. The related postings, such as revenue recognition, revenue adjustment from invoice correction and balance sheet postings, are posted directly with the revenue contract and performance obligation IDs.  These identifiers are essential for:

  • Tracing postings back to revenue contracts
  • Supporting reconciliation and audit processes
  • Enabling detailed margin and revenue analysis
  • Improving user efficiency in daily operations

While Manage Journal Entries allows filtering by these fields, it does not provide the same line‑item list view that business users rely on. Adding the fields to the line‑item apps closes this gap.

What You Need Before You Start

This enhancement requires:

  • Access to the Custom Fields app (Extensibility role from the template role: SAP_BR_EXTENSIBLITY_SPEC)
  • No technical development or custom fields — SAP delivers the fields already in ACDOCA

Time required: 20–30 minutes.

Step‑by‑Step Guide: Adding the Fields

Step 1 — Open the Custom Fields App

Navigate to: Extensibility → Custom Fields

This app allows you to extend SAP‑delivered UIs with additional fields.

Step 2 — Create a Data Source Extension

Go to the Data Source Extension tab, and Click Create

Select the data source extension FAC_GLV_GL_ACCOUNT_LINE_ITEMS_SRV ( Display Line Items in General Ledger )

Enter a description (SAP will propose an extension ID automatically).  Example: Revenue Contract

Click Create to continue

Step 3 — Add the Required Fields

In the field selection screen,  click the Search icon.

Search for Revenue Accounting Contract.

Select the field and click Apply.

Repeat the process for Performance Obligation / Performance Application

These fields exist in the Universal Journal but are not part of the default field catalog — which is why this extension is necessary.

Step 4 — Publish the Extension

Accept the default labels,  Click Save & Publish.

SAP will now add these fields to the field catalog of the relevant apps.  Publishing may take a few minutes.

Step 5 — Verify the Fields in the Apps

Open Display Line Items in General Ledger (and similarly Margin Analysis)

In the Filter Bar

Click Adapt Filters and confirm that you now see:

  • Revenue Accounting Contract
  • Performance Obligation

In the List View

Open Settings → Adapt Columns and add:

  • Revenue Accounting Contract
  • Performance Obligation

These fields can now be used for filtering, sorting, and reporting.

Recommended Best Practice

In the Fiori App ‘Display Line Items in General Ledger’ and ‘Display Line Items in Margin Analysis’,  you can create and save a custom view that includes these fields and share it with business users. This ensures consistent reporting across the project

Summary

Adding Revenue Contract and Performance Obligation IDs to the line‑item apps is:

  • Simple — no coding required
  • SAP‑standard — uses delivered extensibility
  • Valuable — improves transparency and analysis
  • Fast — completed in under 30 minutes

This enhancement is especially useful for organizations implementing Contract‑Based Revenue Recognition and wanting to streamline operational reporting.
